advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://osaki.cool.ne.jp/hc/computer/canon/canon.html#x07">Handheld computer & Pocket calculator Museum</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>1982 - It was the time when one still lacked good programs for the IBM PC...<br><br> Advert said: <font color="#666666"><br><br> Attention, all programmers. Here's a chance to reach the top.<br> If you've written software that's completed and runs on the IBM Personal Computer (or another computer), we could be interested in publishing it...<br> ... We select programs that will make the IBM Personal Computer an even more useful toll for modern times...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SIL'Z III</strong></font><br><blockquote>Nice fish-eye picture of a Sil'z III illustrating a 1982 article about Technologic Revolution in the french mag TeleSoft.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT - FEB.1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>“Why be content with a video game system?<br> Today, the VIC-20 is available at a special price.”<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (SEPTEMBER 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Sorry, you don't play with me"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to datareign.co.uk for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1ST. U.S. ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Each picture represents a customers target. Three of them are well known: Home/entertainement, office and educational uses. A fourth one is added for the first time, the senior citizens. Epson thought the QX-10 was user-friendly enough to be used by retired people. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MBC-550 FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The personal computer 550, an opened door upon you computing future''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (AUG. 86)</strong></font><br><blockquote>U.K. prices:<br> Monochrome: <b>£299</b><br> Colour: <b>£399</b></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Thanks to <a href="http://blogs.linux.ie/fuzzbucket/archives/p/7/more/1/c/1/Vintage-Sinclair-QL-catalogue" target="_blank">fuzzbucket</a> for this complete QL catalogue.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">Soichiro Oga</a> for this picture !</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Rui Santos for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"After the compliments made to the Amstrad CPC-464, what could be added ?"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juan Antonio Maestre for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Yes, it's really him – William Shatner (Captain Kirk).<br> Did they really use VIC-20 in the Enterprise?<br> That would certainly explain a lot of things...<p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1976)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAGAZINE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Gridcase made the cover of SVM (french magazine) in january 1985</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"MO5. Adventure built-in"<br> "All the world in a present"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Welcome in the world of the "clean"-computers"<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRINTERS ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>The display says: "Personal computer Pravetz 82"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Bojidar Stefanov</b></p></blockquote>

computer.description:
Very little is known about this obscure Argentinian console! Though it uses a very similar Atari 2600 Jr case, This console if just a cheap copy of the Nintendo Famicom / NES.
In Argentina, several clone systems like can be found. A few can still be bought with cartridges for around 40 or 50 u$s.
computer.name: Activision Family Game
computer.ports: Two controller connectors, cartidge slot, power in, video output, expansion connector

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ACTIVISION FAMILY GAME</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://compuclasico.homelinux.net" target="_blank">Ricardo Saucedo</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BOTTOM</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://compuclasico.homelinux.net" target="_blank">Ricardo Saucedo</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://compuclasico.homelinux.net" target="_blank">Ricardo Saucedo</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DETAIL</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://compuclasico.homelinux.net" target="_blank">Ricardo Saucedo</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> OPENED</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://compuclasico.homelinux.net" target="_blank">Ricardo Saucedo</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
